title: How has the percentage of smokers quitting changed?
analysis_commentary:
Though smoking prevalence has fallen in the last decade, the health consequences of smoking present a major health challenge. The Stop Smoking Services is judged by the number of people who quit smoking within a certain time period.

The highest proportion of quitters was seen in 2003/04, when 57% of people who set a quit date quit smoking within four weeks. In 2003/04, the Department of Health's first integrated smoking campaign launched, which included the first campaigns designed to be highly emotional, which may have been responsible (http://smokefree.nhs.uk/resources/campaign/). Since then, the proportion of quitters has steadily declined to the lowest level of 49% in 2009/10, where it has since remained. However, the number of people setting a quit date as part of the NHS Stop Smoking Scheme has been increasing, from around 230,000 in 2001/02 to a high of roughly 820,000 in 2011/12. The net result is that more people are reporting quitting after four weeks.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Statistics on NHS Stop Smoking Services in England
